subject: Art
title: Sharpening & Noise Reduction
description: The final polish â€” enhancing detail and reducing grain.

hook.text: RAW files look slightly soft by default â€” the sensor captures data without applying sharpening. Noise reduction smooths grain from high ISO. These are the finishing touches â€” like seasoning a dish before serving.

buildup.text: Sharpening: increases edge contrast to make details look crisp. Applied in small amounts â€” too much creates halos and artifacts. Noise reduction: smooths random grain â€” too much creates a waxy, detail-less look.

discovery.text: The trade-off: sharpening enhances detail but also enhances noise. Noise reduction removes noise but also softens detail. They're opposing forces. The art is finding the balance where detail is crisp and noise is controlled.

twist.text: Output-specific sharpening: images for web (small, viewed on screen) need less sharpening than prints (large, viewed up close). Always sharpen LAST in your workflow, and sharpen differently for each output medium.

climax.text: Compare: a RAW file with no sharpening (soft), light sharpening (crisp), and heavy sharpening (crunchy with halos). Then view at actual display size rather than 200% zoom. The light sharpening always looks best at normal viewing distance.

punchline.text: Sharpen gently. Reduce noise sparingly. The best edits are the ones nobody can see.

quiz.question: What happens if you apply too much sharpening?
options: Halos appear around edges and noise is enhanced
